title: Wednesday, 29th March, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM11:01am

Morning

PM11:01am

So it's happened.

PM11:01am

Brexit triggered

11:01 am
PM11:02am

Jack knife market reaction

PM11:02am

Footsie off three points

PM11:02am

Sterling weakened then recovered

PM11:03am

To mark this historic occasion you get Part II of the PR crap that lands in my inbox on important days like this

PM11:03am

29/03/17: Ahead of the triggering of Article 50, Ed Molyneux, CEO and co-founder of FreeAgent, who provide award-winning cloud accounting software to freelancers, micro-businesses and their accountants said:

“The triggering of Article 50 is a decision that the UK’s micro-business owners will have great concerns about, so I hope that the government will take their views into consideration as it negotiates our exit from the EU.

PM11:03am

invstr is an investment game app that lets you play the markets, learn and share. Our mission is to make finance social by democratizing access to information and empowering everyone to take charge of their financial future.

https://invstr.com/

BE11:05am

11:05 am

That's kinda what we do, eh Bryce?

BE11:06am

Democratising access to information and empowering folk? Sure, why not.

PM11:06am

Ah, i knew i remembered this name

11:06 am
PM11:06am

A City merchant banker felt disappointed and mistreated after being paid just $500,000 (£320,000) for a year's work, the High Court heard yesterday.
Vast amounts paid to Kerim Derhalli, 40, were revealed on the first day of his claim for $16.5 million, the largest pay claim to be brought in a court in this country.
Shortly after being head-hunted to Lehman Brothers, he was paid $1 million (£640,000) after completing two months' work for the American investment bank.

PM11:06am

That's from about 15 years ago

http://www.telegra...s-16m-lawsuit.html

(@Lemmy: yes and no. There's a branch of flackery whose jobs involve explaining important, technical stuff to us and making sure we don't write nonsense. They're mostly government employees.)

11:08 am

I mean ... imagine being a CEO and believing it's a valuable use of VC money to pay -- pay! -- a Feltcollaredsource to send out your thoughts on current events.

PM11:09am

UK Prime Minister Theresa May will today formally notify the president of the European Council of the country's intention to leave the EU. Please find below a comment from Hartwig Kos, co-head of multi-asset and vice-CIO at SYZ Asset Management, assessing the potential implications once Article 50 is triggered.

If you have any questions, or would like any further information, please don’t hesitate to get in touch.

Best wishes,

PM11:09am

Do we want some proper Brexit grey?

11:09 am
BE11:09am

Sure. Why not.

PM11:10am

Malcolm Barr -- he's always reliable and readable

PM11:10am

Our base case…

Our base case remains that the EU exit will ultimately be delayed until late 2019 (as there will be mutual interest in creating more time for discussion), and that the UK leaves the EU on the basis of a patchwork of arrangements which are substantively incomplete. In the goods sector, we expect the arrangements will work toward replicating the status quo, with the UK still largely bound to follow EU product definitions and regulations. In the services sector, the arrangements will likely entail a more distinct step down in the scope of the UK’s market access as exit occurs, and will suggest that some of the access that has been retained is on a more tenuous basis than in the goods sector.

11:10 am
PM11:10am

While arrangements in some sectors are still being discussed the jurisdiction of the ECJ will still apply. Even in this “messy agreement” scenario we foresee significant potential for disruption to trade flows as the exit occurs, as the time to put in place the legal, administrative, and practical mechanisms to support the day to day business of trade will be short as the UK becomes a “third party” from the point of view of the EU. In our view the probability of the UK leaving the EU without a formal deal covering future trade arrangements, and reverting to WTO rules, is worryingly high at around one in three.

PM11:10am

On the letter (and its aftermath)…..

With both the UK and the EU having set out large parts of their views on the process already, the immediate interaction between the two parties will likely bring incremental news. At issue in tomorrow’s letter is the (a) whether May begins to accept the need for a process of determining the extent of the UK’s liability upon departure, and (b) the extent to which the UK continues to push for a parallel start to trade and other discussions, rather than accepting the sequential process the EU has stated it will follow.

PM11:10am

The EU side of the discussion has been relatively disciplined in keeping views on how the issues should be handled aligned up until now, partly as by-product of attempts to avoid ‘pre-negotiation’ ahead of Article 50 notification. Our expectation, however, is that there will be no shortage of views being expressed as we go forward from here; part of the challenge will be establishing how representative of positions that will actually be taken in the negotiations these statements are. Donald Tusk will respond to the Article 50 notification with a draft of his negotiating guidelines for the Council by the end of this week. Those guidelines are expected to be formally adopted at a European Council summit scheduled for April 29th . The Commission will then turn those into a more detailed set of “negotiating directives” to be agreed by the Council before formal discussions with the UK begin, likely in late May or early June.

11:11 am
PM11:11am

Barr's also got about a dozen links to specific Brexit stuff from JPM, but I can't share cos of watermarking

PM11:11am

Angry smile

PM11:11am

Let's leave it there

Well okay. I mean .... We're into "financial markets price things in probabilities of things happening rather than actual happenings, and Article 50 has been on 99.9% probability for ages" territory. Still, a recap is always useful, particularly when it's a readable one.

PM11:12am

Hmm

Ahead of the triggering of Article 50 at 12:30pm, I wanted to see if you might be interested in a comment from Michelle McGrade, chief investment officer at TD Direct Investing?

3i Group PLC (III:LSE): Last: 720.50, up 20 (+2.86%), High: 731.50, Low: 714.50, Volume: 701.74k

BE11:23am

11:23 am
BE11:23am

The Benelux junk retailer that makes up a fair bit of 3i's portfolio

BE11:24am

And a company that makes me think Woolworths really missed a trick by dying.

BE11:24am

Because it seems like Trevor Bish-Jones was some kind of visionary.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

Action -- which let's face it is Woolworths transplanted into continental Europe and detoxed of leases and pensions -- is apparently an "exceptional" business worth more than €10bn.

BE11:25am

This is what we're talking about.

BE11:25am

11:25 am
PM11:25am

Sheesh

BE11:25am

That's the French site. Flower pots and knock-off Crocs.

BE11:25am

I'll let MOST explain he attraction.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

B&M is a great business, in our view; however, it doesn't fare particularly well in a side-by-side comparison with Action. We believe Action could be worth €10bn+ (more than 250p per 3i share). This is not reflected in 3i's share price, so we upgrade to Overweight.

PM11:26am

10bn?!?!?!

BE11:26am

We have undertaken a detailed comparison of Action and B&M. With Action becoming such an important component of 3i's investment portfolio, we have taken a detailed look at the company alongside B&M (which we believe to be Action's closest listed peer). Most of this report is devoted to a detailed, side-byside comparison of the two businesses.
We are big fans of both businesses, but Action looks exceptional to us...
Somewhat to our surprise, the comparison leaves us of the view that Action is the more attractive asset. Both companies enjoy compelling economic models, face a limited threat from online competition and are growing very rapidly.
However, Action has a more advanced (and thus more proven) international expansion strategy, a much more favourable working capital cycle and is delivering better sales densities, even higher returns and better cash conversion.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

...and we now think 3i's stake could be worth more than 250p per share. Until now we have valued 3i's stake in Action using EBITDA multiples (as 3i itself does), at €5.5bn based on 2016 EBITDA (vs 3i's estimate of €5.2bn or 142p per share as at Dec 2016). However, we feel that this does not fully capture Action's longterm growth potential or its unusual level of cash generation. Using a DCF, with undemanding assumptions, we believe that Action could be worth in excess of €10bn, implying that 3i's stake could be worth more than 250p per 3i share.

BE11:27am

We upgrade 3i to Overweight with a new price target of 823p. Even though we apply a 20% haircut to our DCF valuation, our NAV-based price target for 3i increases to 823p, leading us to upgrade our rating to Overweight. However, the implied EBITDA multiple for Action is still very high (22.5x CY17 EBITDA), so there is a risk that investors will not be prepared to value Action (or therefore 3i) as highly as we do. We assume 142p per share in our bear case, in line with 3i's estimated value, but the underlying assumptions there – much lower store rollout and 1% sales per store growth and 0% terminal growth – appear overly bearish in our view.

BE11:28am

Yes, that says 22.5x CY17 EBITDA.

The Novo Nordisk Foundation is a Danish foundation with corporate interests. The Foundation has two objectives: 1) to provide a stable basis for the commercial and research activities of the companies in the Novo Group; and 2) to support scientific, humanitarian and social purposes.

The vision of the Foundation is to contribute significantly to research and development that improves the health and welfare of people.

It is worth noting we have seen significant multiple expansion at both Coloplast and Smith & Nephew (particularly the former) very recently. At our price target of 305p, ConvaTec shares would be trading on a FY18 PER of 17.2x. The shares continue to trade at a PE discount to both Smith & Nephew and Coloplast.

BE11:38am

And on indexing ....

11:38 am

The placing is likely to generate a reasonably significant amount of index demand. Most notably, by breaking the lock-up early (was due to expire 29 April), the company is a contender for inclusion in the MSCI series in May (announcement 15 May, effective 31 May).

BE11:39am

Goldman also keen.

BE11:39am

We continue to believe that current valuation (1 5.6x
201 8E P/E and 6.3% 201 8E FCF yield) is undemanding in the context of our expectation
for a 1 0% EPS CAGR (201 7-2021 E) and compared to EU Medtech peers trading at 1 9.7x
P/E and 5.2% FCF yield for a 1 2% EPS CAGR (201 6-2020E).

Our 1 2-month, P/E-based target of 31 0p assumes ConvaTec trades at 1 8x P/E (201 8E), a
1 0% discount to EU Medtech, reflecting the company’s inferior organic revenue and EPS
growth outlook, but superior returns. At our price target, ConvaTec would trade at
almost a 30% discount to Coloplast and a c.1 0% premium to Smith & Nephew. Key
risks to our view include: failure to turn around the performance in ostomy, lack of
market share gains and/or losses, competitive pressure, loss of long-term contracts,
execution on the MIP, and US$/Eur and US$/GBP

PM11:41am

With a blinding spotlight on Snap's IPO, viral powerhouse BuzzFeed is quietly making preparations to go public in 2018, industry sources tell me. OMG!

11:41 am
PM11:41am

https://www.axios....18-2334551408.html

PM11:42am

The widely (and poorly) copied BuzzFeed, which began as a "great cat site" and now has foreign correspondents and a massive BuzzFeed Motion Pictures studio in L.A., mastered the art of sharable content and became a defining brand of the Internet age.

The pitch: BuzzFeed, with news and entertainment divisions, styles itself as a media-tech company with "the innovation obsessed culture and structure of a venture-backed tech company": "We are best known for exploding watermelons, The Dress, Tasty, award-winning news investigations, quizzes, and lists."
The strategy: BuzzFeed CEO Jonah Peretti has turned down past offers from media companies, and has long planned to go public.
Peers: The Big Four of modern digital content companies are BuzzFeed, Vox, Vice and Group Nine Media (millennial-focused online publishers Thrillist, NowThis, The Dodo and Seeker).
All have partnered with traditional media companies: NBC invested in BuzzFeed and Vox (and is an investor in Axios), Disney invested in Vice, and Discovery invested in Group Nine.
"Vice wants to sell," a top industry source said.

PM11:42am

What do we make of Axios?

11:42 am
PM11:42am

As a source for news like this, i mean

BE11:43am

Not sure. That all sounds reasonable, if a bit light on the sourcing.

BE11:43am

I mean, it makes sense. We can go into the argument once more that equity markets are for VC to take money out of mature businesses at risk of going ex growth, and Buzzfeed certainly hits that definition.

11:43 am
PM11:43am

Well, there is no sourcing. But then we've been guilty of that on occasion

BE11:44am

Glass houses -- yes.

PM11:44am

The Axios Manifesto

11:44 am
PM11:44am

All of us left cool, safe jobs to start a new company with this shared belief: Media is broken — and too often a scam.

Stories are too long. Or too boring. Web sites are a maddening mess. Readers and advertisers alike are too often afterthoughts. They get duped by headlines that don't deliver and distracted by pop-up nonsense or unworthy clicks. Many now make money selling fake headlines, fake controversies and even fake news.

Can you imagine Ford being obsessed mainly with whether the engineers love the howl and design of the F-150 engine, instead of simply delivering an awesome truck people want to drive? Never. But that's what digital media companies too often do. They produce journalism the way journalists want to produce it. And they design their products to maximize short-term buzz or revenue — not deliver the best experience possible.

We are engineering Axios around a simple proposition: Deliver the cleanest, smartest, most efficient and trust-worthy experience for readers and advertisers alike.

BE11:45am

Sure, fine.

PM11:45am

Media is broken — and too often a scam. -- there is some truth to this

Mr. Shore remains Executive Chairman of the Group and will focus on its international investment strategy, including developing new relationships as well as investment opportunities.

JRP Group PLC (JRP:LSE): Last: 132.70, down 6.2 (-4.46%), High: 137.20, Low: 132.00, Volume: 3.36m
PM11:56am

A par from Panmure

11:57 am
PM11:57am

Last night there was an announcement flagging a proposed Placing of c75m ordinary shares in JRP. However, this morning it has been confirmed that 95m shares representing c10.2% of the issued share capital was sold at 130p/share via an accelerated book build for the two original PE owners - Cinven (c38m shares) and Permira (c57m shares). Combined they will still own c38.7% of the shares (Cinven 15.5%, Permira 23.2%) although they are subject to a lock up for 90 days post Placing completion (subject to waiver). Whilst we welcome the move to create additional liquidity we suspect that there will be a stock overhang in the short/medium term. On the positive side the stock overhang is lower than it was previously. The underlying business is doing well as shown in the better than expected 2016 year end results released early February. We maintain our Buy recommendation and 207p/share target price

BE11:58am

Okay, while you were doing that I was scanning through sellside.

Otherwise, we have JPM selling Polymetal.

PM12:00pm

hehehe

BE12:01pm

Polymetal’s shares have outperformed the Philadelphia Gold Index by greater than 30%
since Jun’15 as Rouble-denominated gold prices rose greater than 50% over the period.
However, we now view Polymetal’s 9x EV/EBITDA as expensive and
inadequately discounting the impact of Rouble strengthening and the risk of
improving Russian economic conditions. We estimate $781m 2018E EBITDA
at current gold prices, which is greater than 20% below B’Berg 28 day consensus. We
downgrade to Underweight with a £9.80/sh YE'17 PT and we identify
Polymetal as our least preferred UK-listed gold equity on valuation grounds.

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

Here they are on the gold price.

BE12:01pm

JPM expects gold prices to be
supported at ~$1,200/oz-1,350/oz in 2017-18. We believe gold retains
attractive investment appeal as a hedge against inflationary surprises,
compressed real rates and “black-swan” type political risks. Our global
investment framework is to prefer equities that offer 1) stock specific equity
re-rating catalysts; 2) a credible roadmap for growing exposure to the gold
price and grow total shareholder returns in a flat gold price environment;
and 3) attractive valuation support. Given its impressive share price rise
since 2015, Polymetal no longer complies with 1) and 2), in our view.

BE12:01pm

And here they are on the Polymetal price.

12:01 pm
BE12:02pm

We calculate Polymetal is the second most expensive, major UK
gold producer on 1.6x P/NPV. Mark to market EV/EBITDA of 9x is more than 1SD
above its 7.0x average since listing in 2011, which implies downside risk in
our view. We downgrade to UW (N) with a £9.80/sh YE’17 PT (£6.80/sh).
